note.body:
I am experiencing the same error. Both "zenity --question" and "zenity --calendar" segfault for me. I have not tested other ways of invoking zenity. I am attaching a stacktrace from "coredumpctl info". I am using "zenity --calendar" as a sanity check. A python script that uses zenity (lug-helper) is crashing so I did some basic checks to look into why.

[stacktrace.txt](/uploads/9ff36b3c36147064a7ccba5c99f5ab7a/stacktrace.txt)

Basic System Info:
```
window manager: Sway
distro: Archlinux
uname -a: Linux endora 6.6.60-1-lts 1# SMP PREEMPT_DYNAMIC Fri, 08 Nov 2024 16:03:02 +0000 x86_64 GNU/Linux
zenity --version: 4.0.3
gpu: AMD 7900xtx
```

Doing a little more investigation "AMD_VULKAN_ICD=RADV zenity --calendar" works while "AMD_VULKAN_ICD=amdvlk zenity --calendar" does not.

With a bit more digging. "AMD_VULKAN_ICD=amdvlk vulkaninfo" also segfaults while "AMD_VULKAN_ICD=RADV vulkaninfo" works without issue. With this info it seems that my segmentation fault is probably caused by the amdvlk driver or some way GTK is interacting with the amdvlk driver.

target_title: zenity windows are white on white under OSX 15.1

note.body:
> zenity 3.42.1

Hi @splaisan, thanks for reporting this. Unfortunately you are using a 31 month old version which is not supported anymore by GNOME developers. There will not be any bug fixes or feature additions by GNOME developers for the version that you use.

Please feel free to reopen this issue if this situation still happens with a more recent version.

You could also bring this up in a support forum instead: https://discourse.gnome.org/

note.body:
So over and above my conservatism with bumping GTK deps - one unfortunate side effect is that we not only lose the `--show-palette` option (not a bit loss IMHO) but we also lose the ability to add custom ok/cancel buttons and extra buttons.

I mean, technical limitations are one thing - APIs come and go, get deprecated, etc. But I've looked into this deeper, and it's not like we're getting some shiny new color selection dialog by switching to this API - if you look at the GTK source code, all it does is call the deprecated GtkColorChooserDialog API internally. So right now using the new API it's "6 of one, half a dozen of the other." And we lose functionality in the process.

So again, I think I'm going to keep this on the back-burner for now. It will surely come in handy in the future since the API will fully be gone by GTK5, for instance. And who knows, a shiny new color dialog may actually appear in the GTK4 dev cycle that makes it worth dropping functionality for.

I think this can be left in, but `s/dialog/NULL`. As a side note: These macros in util.h are admittedly pretty gross and I think in the near future when I get a bit of time I'll replace them with inline functions or something much cleaner. (I was pretty macro-happy at the time; I've since learned from then ;-)
Just a wee nitpick but let's keep the asterisk on the right-hand side in the idiomatic GNOME style (as opposed to the C++ style).

This is a bit confusing because the docs don't really make this clear (I just brought this up in `#GTK` on Matrix) but these dialog async functions all utilize the `GTK_DIALOG_ERROR` domain - so instead of hardcoding `2` it would be best to do a switch statement or if block based on this enum type - we should cover all possibilities and either abort via `g_assert_not_reached ()` with a non-handled enum retval, or perhaps print an error to stderr and quit zenity.

This has almost zero context so as to be actionable. `zenity --question` doesn't cause a crash for all zsh users; if that were the case, we'd have way more reports than just this. I also tried myself and could not reproduce. What version of zenity are you running? If core was dumped, could you provide the core file, or a gdb backtrace?

tree: Fix glib warning when getting items from stdin

note.body:
Ah, sorry. I didn't realize that it was intended behavior that the ui would update when new data comes in.

As far as I can tell GIOChannel is still the best API in glib for what we want to do or do you have a better idea? Otherwise I would just try a bit around to fix the issue without destroying the functionality in the test case.

target_title: tree: Fix glib warning when getting items from stdin

note.body: It does fix the warning as described, but it also causes the `test_named_pipe.sh` test to fail. The stdin code in tree.c is kind of suboptimal. Perhaps a bit of a deeper dive is needed.

Looks good, but GtkColorDialog is not available till GTK 4.10, and I'm not ready to bump the requirement yet. So we'll keep this open for now. I'm guessing in about 12 months' time I'll be ready to bump it.

And I would say yes, let's add a deprecation warning ala the other deprecated options. When it's ready to be merged, it will then be ready to go.
